He has been experiencing worsening altered mental status, tachypnea, and fevers. The patient was found intoxicated and lying outside by his daughter, and at the emergency department, he was found to have a small right intraparenchymal hemorrhage and SAH. He was loaded with phenytoin and transferred to Hospital1. Neurosurgery did not operate, and his mental status has been stable. He has been febrile for a few days and has sputum positive for gram-negative rods (GNRs). He has been prescribed vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and azithromycin for presumed pneumonia, although his chest X-ray was benign. He also has hyponatremia with a sodium level of 128 on 3/28/2177. He has not required CIWA. He was transferred to medicine for further management. On the evening of 3/28/2177, the patient became tachypneic and unresponsive. A head CT showed a stable bleed, and a chest CT angiography was negative for pulmonary embolism but showed likely aspirated material in the right bronchus. He was admitted to the MICU for further management. An arterial blood gas on transfer
